message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has advanced prostate cancer with bone metastases, which calls for androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). Flutamide is an antiandrogen medication used in combination with ADT in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer. Leuprolide, Degarelix, and Docetaxel are also used in the treatment of prostate cancer but do not specifically target androgen receptors like Flutamide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and signs suggestive of prostate cancer with imaging studies showing osteoblastic lesions. Flutamide is a non-steroidal antiandrogen agent used in the treatment of prostate cancer by blocking the androgen receptor. Leuprolide, Degarelix, and Docetaxel are other drugs used in the management of prostate cancer but they have different mechanisms of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results indicate prostate cancer, and the CT scan shows bone metastases. Flutamide is an antiandrogen medication used in combination with other drugs to treat prostate cancer by competing with androgens for interaction with the testosterone receptors. Leuprolide and degarelix are gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists used to reduce testosterone levels, and docetaxel is a chemotherapy drug used for advanced prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of advanced prostate cancer with bone metastasis, and the high PSA level and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis. Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist that is used in combination with other treatments like leuprolide to treat advanced prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy results suggest prostate cancer, and the presence of osteoblastic lesions on CT scan indicates metastasis. The drug that competes with androgens for interaction with the testosterone receptors is called antiandrogen therapy. Flutamide is a type of antiandrogen therapy commonly used for prostate cancer. Leuprolide, Degarelix, and Docetaxel are other treatments for prostate cancer but work through different mechanisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest prostate cancer with bone metastases. Flutamide is a nonsteroidal antiandrogen agent that competitively inhibits the testosterone receptors in the prostate gland, which can help alleviate symptoms and slow the progression of the cancer. Leuprolide is a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone agonist that can also be used to suppress testosterone production, but it is not the first-line treatment for symptoms or bone pain. Degarelix is also a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone antagonist but it is used for advanced prostate cancer that has spread beyond the prostate gland. Docetaxel is a chemotherapy agent that can be used in combination with androgen deprivation therapy for advanced prostate cancer, but it is not the initial treatment for symptoms or bone pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, rectal exam findings, and biopsy results suggest prostate cancer, which is treated using androgen deprivation therapy. Flutamide is a medication that blocks androgen receptors and is commonly used in combination with luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone agonists like Leuprolide. Degarelix is a newer medication with similar effects. Docetaxel is a chemotherapy drug typically used in advanced prostate cancer. However, the question specifically mentions a drug that competes with androgens for interaction with testosterone receptors, which indicates Flutamide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has prostate cancer and bone metastases, indicating hormone-sensitive prostate cancer. Flutamide is a nonsteroidal antiandrogen drug that competes with androgens for interaction with the testosterone receptors and can be used for this purpose. Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone analog that decreases testosterone production and can also be used in hormone-sensitive prostate cancer, but it was not the most likely drug initiated in this patient because it was not one of the answer options. Degarelix and Docetaxel are used in advanced prostate cancer but not specifically in hormone-sensitive prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the biopsy results suggest prostate cancer. The CT scan showing osteoblastic lesions indicates prostate cancer metastasis to the bone. Flutamide is an anti-androgen drug that competes with androgens for interaction with the testosterone receptors and can be used to treat prostate cancer. Leuprolide, Degarelix, and Docetaxel are other treatment options for prostate cancer, but they work differently than Flutamide.

Among the options, only Flutamide competes with androgens for interaction with the testosterone receptors. Leuprolide, Degarelix, and Docetaxel are also used in the treatment of prostate cancer, but each has a different mechanism of action.
